custom_item_1.description: FireEye - Configuration auditing logs the required number of changes
custom_item_1.info: Saving past configurations allows them to be audited for unauthorized changes and reviewed when troubleshooting. Auditing cannot be disabled but can be set to 1, significantly reducing effectiveness. Configuration changes can be exported through the Log Manager.
custom_item_1.solution:
The default value is 1000. Edit the configuration and add or modify this line:\n

configuration audit max-changes 1000

custom_item_2.description: FireEye - Local logging level includes all errors and warnings
custom_item_2.info: Logs should include message levels of 'notice' and above. Higher levels such as 'crit' and 'err' do not include warnings of impending problems or notices of administrative actions.
custom_item_2.solution:
The default level is 'notice'. Edit the configuration and add or modify this line:\n

logging local

custom_item_3.description: FireEye - Local logging level is not overridden except by defaults
custom_item_3.info: Logs should include message levels of 'notice' and above. By default two event classes are overridden with a priority of 'notice'. If additional overrides are found logs may not contain all expected events.
custom_item_3.solution: If other overrides are present remove them by editing the configuration and entering 'no' before the override to be removed.
custom_item_3.expect: logging local override class mgmt-(back|front) priority notice

custom_item_4.info:
Log retention should be reviewed to ensure logs are available to troubleshoot issues and investigate incidents. FireEye can rotate logs based on log size, size as a percentage of the /var partition, or a set period of time.

  NOTE: Nessus has provided the target output to assist in reviewing the benchmark to ensure target compliance.
custom_item_4.solution:
Determine what works best based on your log generation, device capabilities, and organizational standards. Edit the configuration and add or modify these lines:\n

logging files rotation criteria frequency\n
logging files rotation criteria [size|size-pct]\n
logging files rotation max-num

custom_item_5.info: Security log information could be modified or lost if the host is compromised or fails. Syslog messages should be sent to a remote host.
custom_item_5.solution:
The default level is 'notice'. Edit the configuration and add or modify this line:\n

logging

custom_item_6.description: FireEye - Remote syslog logging level includes all errors and warnings
custom_item_6.info: Syslog messages sent to a remote host should include message levels of 'notice' and above. Higher levels such as 'crit' and 'err' do not include warnings of impending problems or notices of administrative actions.
custom_item_6.solution:
Check organizational standards to determine the appropriate level for this appliance. Edit the configuration and add or modify this line:\n

loggingtrap\n

Omit the trap parameter to use the default level, 'notice'.

custom_item_7.info: An accurate clock is essential for log analysis and correlation with other devices. NTP must be enabled to synchronize with other devices.
custom_item_7.solution:
Edit the configuration and add this line:\n

ntp enable

custom_item_8.description: FireEye - NTP client uses a custom server
custom_item_8.info:
If no custom NTP servers are specified the appliance will utilize default servers on the Internet which may not be reachable.

  NOTE: Nessus has provided the target output to assist in reviewing the benchmark to ensure target compliance.
custom_item_8.solution:
Check organizational standards to determine the appropriate NTP server for this appliance. Edit the configuration and add or modify this line:\n

ntp server

custom_item_9.info: An accurate clock is essential for log analysis and correlation with other devices. This check looks at the current synchronization status of the appliance.
custom_item_9.solution: Review other checks covering NTP configuration and ensure it is set appropriately. Run the 'ntp' command from the appliance to verify connectivity with the chosen NTP servers.

custom_item_10.info: The configured time zone should be reviewed. By default Greenwich Mean Time (GMT) is used. Some organizations prefer a unified time zone across the organization while others use the time zone of the appliance's physical location. Accurate and coordinated clocks are essential for auditing appliance logs.
custom_item_10.solution:
Check organizational standards to determine the appropriate time zone for this appliance. Edit the configuration and add or modify this line:\n

clock timezone

custom_item_11.info:
The list of users should be reviewed.

  NOTE: Nessus has provided the target output to assist in reviewing the benchmark to ensure target compliance.

custom_item_12.info: The list of administrative users should be reviewed.

custom_item_13.description: FireEye - User connections are limited by subnet or VLAN
custom_item_13.info:
Remote connections to the appliance should be restricted to specific subnets or VLANs to limit opportunities for unauthorized access. These restrictions are assigned per user.

  NOTE: Nessus has provided the target output to assist in reviewing the benchmark to ensure target compliance.
custom_item_13.solution:
Edit the configuration and add or modify this line for each user:\n

username[subnet|vlan]

custom_item_14.description: FireEye - User 'admin' SSH access is disabled
custom_item_14.info: The default username cannot be removed and could be used by an attacker in an attempt to log in. It should be available for local logins in case of emergencies but remote access should be disabled.
custom_item_14.solution:
Create another administrative user for remote access and disable such access for the 'admin' account. Edit the configuration and add these lines:\n

usernamecapability admin\n
no username admin access network enable
custom_item_14.expect: no username admin access network enable

custom_item_15.info: The appliance authenticates users remotely through LDAP, RADIUS, or TACACS+. This can simplify and improve management of users with access to the appliance.
custom_item_15.solution:
Determine which, if any, AAA solutions will be used. Edit the configuration and modify this line, putting the solutions in priority order with 'local' first:\n

aaa authentication login default local [ldap radius tacacs+]

custom_item_17.description: FireEye - AAA tries local authentication first
custom_item_17.info: The appliance authenticates locally first to obviate the risk of local appliance account access issues. If not successful it tries LDAP, RADIUS, and TACACS+ authentication in turn and in the order specified (they can be in any order).
custom_item_17.solution:
Determine which, if any, AAA solutions will be used. Edit the configuration and modify this line, putting the solutions in priority order with 'local' first:\n

aaa authentication login default local [ldap radius tacacs+]

custom_item_18.info:
When a user is authenticated remotely they are mapped to a local user. This local user can be an account with the same username as the remote user or may be specified by the remote AAA service. This setting may be remote-only, remote-first, or local-only.

  NOTE: Nessus has provided the target output to assist in reviewing the benchmark to ensure target compliance.

custom_item_19.info:
When a user is authenticated remotely but is not mapped to a specific local account they will be mapped to this local user. If this is a local administrative account ensure only authorized users can be authenticated through AAA.

  NOTE: Nessus has provided the target output to assist in reviewing the benchmark to ensure target compliance.
custom_item_19.solution:
Edit the configuration and modify this line:\n

aaa authorization map default-user

custom_item_20.description: FireEye - AAA failed logins are tracked
custom_item_20.info: Tracking failed logins is the first step toward mitigating password-guessing attacks.
custom_item_20.solution:
Edit the configuration and add this line:\n

aaa authentication attempts track enable

custom_item_21.info: Authentication through AAA will be blocked for a time after a configurable number of failures. This helps mitigate password-guessing attacks.
custom_item_21.solution:
Edit the configuration and add this line:\n

aaa authentication attempts lockout enable

custom_item_22.description: FireEye - AAA lockouts occur after at most 5 failures
custom_item_22.info: Authentication through AAA for the account will be blocked during a lockout. Setting this too high can allow faster password-guessing attacks.
custom_item_22.solution:
Edit the configuration and add this line:\n

aaa authentication attempts lockout max-fail 5

custom_item_23.description: FireEye - AAA lockouts delay further attempts for at least 30 seconds
custom_item_23.info: Authentication through AAA for the account will be blocked during a lockout. Setting this too low can allow faster password-guessing attacks.
custom_item_23.solution:
Edit the configuration and add this line:\n

aaa authentication attempts lockout unlock-time 30

custom_item_24.description: FireEye - AAA lockout settings apply to the 'admin' user
custom_item_24.info: Password-guessing attacks against the 'admin' account may succeed quickly if account lockouts are not enabled.
custom_item_24.solution:
Edit the configuration and add this line:\n

no aaa authentication attempts class-override admin no-lockout
custom_item_24.expect: no aaa authentication attempts class-override admin no-lockout

custom_item_25.description: FireEye - AAA LDAP binding user should not be an admin
custom_item_25.info:
If LDAP is used with Active Directory a non-administrator user is required for searching and browsing AD server records. Review the binding user and ensure it is not a domain admin or other highly privileged account.

  NOTE: Nessus has provided the target output to assist in reviewing the benchmark to ensure target compliance.

custom_item_26.description: FireEye - Web users are logged out after 20 minutes of inactivity or less
custom_item_26.info: Unattended HTTPS sessions with the appliance could be hijacked and reused by an attacker. Sessions should time out quickly if they are not being actively used. This setting is entered as minutes but is stored as seconds.
custom_item_26.solution:
Edit the configuration and add this line:\n

webui auto-logout

custom_item_27.description: FireEye - SSH users are logged out after 15 minutes of inactivity or less
custom_item_27.info: Unattended SSH sessions with the appliance could be hijacked and reused by an attacker. Sessions should time out quickly if they are not being actively used.
custom_item_27.solution:
Edit the configuration and add this line:\n

cli default auto-logout 15

custom_item_28.info:
The login banner should be reviewed to ensure it complies with organizational standards.

  NOTE: Nessus has provided the target output to assist in reviewing the benchmark to ensure target compliance.

custom_item_29.info:
The available and installed guest images should be reviewed. Ensure the selection of enabled images matches the protected organization as closely as possible.

  NOTE: Nessus has provided the target output to assist in reviewing the benchmark to ensure target compliance.
custom_item_29.solution:
To enable a guest image enter the following command:\n

guest-images install

custom_item_30.description: FireEye - Boot image must be signed
custom_item_30.info: Only boot images signed with a trusted signature should be allowed, otherwise the appliance may run malicious or unknown code. Normally boot images are downloaded directly from FireEye but offline update mechanisms are possible.
custom_item_30.solution:
Edit the configuration and add this line:\n

image options require-sig

custom_item_31.description: FireEye - Boot manager password is set
custom_item_31.info: Management of boot images should be protected by a strong password.
custom_item_31.solution:
Edit the configuration and add this line:\n

boot bootmgr password 0

custom_item_32.description: FireEye - System events are emailed to administrators
custom_item_32.info: System-level events including SMART warnings, interface availability changes, and disk space warnings should be monitored by administrators. Email notification can provide the most detail.
custom_item_32.solution:
Edit the configuration and add a line for each recipient:\n

email notify recipient

custom_item_33.info: Intelligent Platform Management Interface (IPMI) provides browser-based troubleshooting access via the appliance's IPMI port or management interface.

custom_item_35.description: FireEye - A scheduled system backup job is configured
custom_item_35.info: A backup of the FireEye database includes configuration settings not found in 'show running-config full' and should be done regularly.
custom_item_35.solution:
Edit the configuration and add these lines:\n

job 123 command 1 'fedb backup to-file backupfile'\n
job 123 command 2 'fedb backup upload backupfile scp://username:password@hostname/path/filename'\n
job 123 schedule type daily time 12:00:00\n
job 123 enable

custom_item_36.description: FireEye - FENet patch updates are applied automatically
custom_item_36.info: Patches are downloaded from the FireEye network (FENet) to remediate vulnerabilities or technical issues in the appliance.

custom_item_37.info:
The list of patches should be reviewed.

  NOTE: Nessus has provided the target output to assist in reviewing the benchmark to ensure target compliance.

custom_item_38.description: FireEye - USB media is not auto-mounted
custom_item_38.info: USB media inserted into the appliance and automatically mounted could provide a way to make malicious files accessible through the appliance web server.
custom_item_38.solution:
Edit the configuration and modify this line:\n

no media usb auto-mount enable

custom_item_39.description: FireEye - SSH connections must be SSHv2
custom_item_39.info: SSH version 1 is insecure and the credentials used could be compromised.
custom_item_39.solution:
Edit the configuration and modify this line:\n

ssh server min-version 2

custom_item_40.info:
Enables support for remote access by Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP). This is enabled by default.

  NOTE: Nessus has provided the target output to assist in reviewing the benchmark to ensure target compliance.
custom_item_40.solution:
Edit the configuration and modify this line:\n

snmp-server enable

custom_item_42.description: FireEye - SNMP uses a secure community string
custom_item_42.info: By default SNMP will use the community string 'public'. Setting a secure community string protects the information available through this service.
custom_item_42.solution:
Edit the configuration and modify this line:\n

snmp-server community[ro]

custom_item_43.description: FireEye - SNMP trap hosts that use community override use a secure community string
custom_item_43.info: By default SNMP will use the community string 'public'. Setting a secure community string protects the information sent to SNMP trap hosts through this service.
custom_item_43.solution: Edit the configuration and use a strong password in any SNMP host community strings.

custom_item_44.description: FireEye - SNMP traps use a secure community string
custom_item_44.info: By default SNMP will use the community string 'public'. Setting a secure community string protects the information sent to SNMP trap hosts through this service that are not specifically configured elsewhere.
custom_item_44.solution:
Edit the configuration and modify this line:\n

snmp-server traps community

custom_item_45.description: FireEye - SNMP v3 uses AES instead of DES
custom_item_45.info: If SNMP v3 users are configured, they can use either DES or AES-128 for confidentiality. The default is AES-128.
custom_item_45.solution:
Edit the configuration and modify this line:\n

snmp-server userv3 prompt auth sha priv aes-128\n
Enter passwords when prompted.
custom_item_45.regex: snmp-server user .+ v3 encrypted auth .+ priv .+
custom_item_45.expect: snmp-server user .+ v3 encrypted auth .+ priv aes-128.+

custom_item_46.description: FireEye - SNMP v3 uses SHA instead of MD5
custom_item_46.info: If SNMP v3 users are configured, they can use either MD5 or SHA for authentication. The default is SHA.
custom_item_46.solution:
Edit the configuration and modify this line:\n

snmp-server userv3 prompt auth sha priv aes-128\n
Enter passwords when prompted.
custom_item_46.expect: snmp-server user .+ v3 encrypted auth sha .+

custom_item_47.description: FireEye - SNMP v3 users have passwords
custom_item_47.info: When SNMP v3 users are created they do not have a password defined. A password should always be used for authentication.
custom_item_47.solution:
Edit the configuration and modify this line:\n

snmp-server userv3 prompt auth sha priv aes-128\n
Enter passwords when prompted.

custom_item_48.description: FireEye - The appliance uses a trusted DNS server
custom_item_48.info: The DNS server IP address should be reviewed. A DNS server may return malicious IP addresses in response to requests for domains that are normally good. This provides an avenue to leak information about the appliance or to download untrusted content.
custom_item_48.solution:
Edit the configuration and modify this line:\n

ip name-server

custom_item_49.description: FireEye - Management interface is only accessible from specific IP ranges
custom_item_49.info: The management interface should only be accessible from trusted portions of the network to limit attack opportunities. The appliance supports an ACL to limit access.
custom_item_49.solution:
Edit the configuration and add this line:\n

management interface allowor\n
management interface allow

custom_item_50.description: FireEye - CLI commands do not hide any settings from administrators
custom_item_50.info: Administrators should be aware of all possible settings on the device so they can protect it effectively. By default all settings are visible but some can be hidden.
custom_item_50.solution:
Edit the configuration and add this line:\n

cli default show config-hidden enable

custom_item_51.description: FireEye - Web interface does not use the system self-signed certificate
custom_item_51.info: A certificate from a trusted CA allows for secure identification of the appliance to clients. Certificates may be loaded through HTTP/FTP/TFTP or SCP.
custom_item_51.solution:
Generate a public/private key pair for the appliance. Once it is installed set it as the default identity certificate. Edit the configuration and add these lines:\n

webui ssl install certificateprivate-key[ca-certificate]\n
crypto certificate default-cert name

custom_item_53.info: By default communications with the LDAP or Active Directory server are unencrypted, leaving credentials visible on the network.
custom_item_53.solution:
Edit the configuration and modify this line:\n

ldap ssl mode [ssl|tls]

custom_item_54.description: FireEye - LDAP encryption certificates are verified
custom_item_54.info: If SSL or TLS encryption is used for LDAP communication then the certificate should be verified to provide assurance it was issued by a trusted CA. An unverified certificate could be duplicated and spoofed.
custom_item_54.solution:
Edit the configuration and modify this line:\n

ldap ssl cert-verify

custom_item_55.description: FireEye - Email encryption certificates are verified
custom_item_55.info: If TLS encryption is used for email communication then the certificate should be verified to provide assurance it was issued by a trusted CA. An unverified certificate could be duplicated and spoofed.
custom_item_55.solution:
Edit the configuration and modify this line:\n

email ssl cert-verify

custom_item_57.description: FireEye - FENet security content update checks are enabled

custom_item_58.description: FireEye - FENet security content updates are configured to run automatically

custom_item_59.description: FireEye - FENet security content updates are scheduled

custom_item_61.info: The product version should be reviewed.

custom_item_62.info: Interfaces operate in pairs called A, B, etc. Two inline modes of operation are supported: detection mode and blocking mode. Detection mode monitors all packets and does not block any traffic. Blocking mode blocks infectious attacks, while allowing all benign packets to pass through the interface. Blocking mode allows you to customize the blocking policy with signatures and whitelists.

custom_item_63.info: If you have configured an appliance for inline blocking mode, you may customize the blocking operation with whitelists. A whitelist is a set of network and/or host addresses. Any communication to or from an address in the whitelist is never blocked.

custom_item_64.description: FireEye - Inline blocking signature policy exceptions
custom_item_64.info: If you have configured an appliance for inline blocking mode, and a blocking event is listed on the Alerts page (in the Blocked column), you may adjust the blocking policy for that event with specific policy exceptions.

custom_item_65.info: If you have configured an appliance for inline blocking mode, you may customize blocking actions such as TCP resets, ICMP notifications, and HTTP comfort pages.

custom_item_66.info:
Greylists provide control over the priority of workorders for known IP addresses and URLs. Greylists contain files that contain either URLs or IP addresses and are used by the FireEye web analysis engine to check if the specified URLs or IP addresses contain a malicious rule match. NOTE: The Greylist page does not display in the Settings tab of the Web MPS GUI until the feature is enabled from the FireEye CLI.

  NOTE: Nessus has provided the target output to assist in reviewing the benchmark to ensure target compliance.
custom_item_66.solution:
Edit the configuration and modify this line:\n

web-analysis greylists enable

custom_item_68.info:
The list of greylist URLs and their contents should be reviewed.

  NOTE: Nessus has provided the target output to assist in reviewing the benchmark to ensure target compliance.

custom_item_69.description: FireEye - Custom SNORT rules are enabled
custom_item_69.info: FireEye Web MPS supports the use of custom rules for malware analysis. It allows end users to load their own format signature rules which will cause the FireEye appliance to detect customer specific traffic patterns and generate alerts.
custom_item_69.solution:
Edit the configuration and modify this line:\n

fenet security-content custom rule enable

custom_item_70.info: YARA is an open source static analysis tool that allows information security analysts to specify byte-level rules that can be used to quickly analyze large quantities of files for relevant matches.
custom_item_70.solution:
Edit the configuration and modify this line:\n

yara policy both

custom_item_71.description: FireEye - YARA policy applies both customer and FireEye rules
custom_item_71.info: YARA is an open source static analysis tool that allows information security analysts to specify byte-level rules that can be used to quickly analyze large quantities of files for relevant matches.
custom_item_71.solution:
Edit the configuration and modify this line:\n

yara policy both

custom_item_72.description: FireEye - Binary analysis AV-suite is enabled
custom_item_72.info: With AV-Suite integration, each infection binary is submitted by the Web MPS to the AV-Suite detection and comparison tool which determines whether antivirus vendors were able to detect the malware that was captured and analyzed by FireEye. The results of AV-Suite assessment are displayed on the Alerts page. FireEye's AV-Suite integration is enabled by default. When enabled, no other configuration is required.
custom_item_72.solution:
Edit the configuration and modify this line:\n

av-suite enable

custom_item_73.description: FireEye - Reports are run on a schedule
custom_item_73.info: Reports should be run on a regular schedule to ease reviews by security administrators.
custom_item_73.solution:
Edit the configuration and add this line:\n

 report schedule runattypetime_framereport_format csv transport

custom_item_74.info:
The list of web-analysis incidents should be reviewed.

  NOTE: Nessus has provided the target output to assist in reviewing the benchmark to ensure target compliance.

custom_item_75.info:
The list of workorders should be reviewed. Each workorder is a request to run code within a virtual environment. If no workorders are being made then the device may be in a clean environment or misconfigured.

  NOTE: Nessus has provided the target output to assist in reviewing the benchmark to ensure target compliance.
